bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, October 23, 1937

div1.p: Hutchison informs Hench that he is interested in highlighting the yellow fever experiments during the upcoming commencement exercises.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, October 23, 1937

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
October 23, 1937

div1.p:
Thanks for your letter. Harriet is
coming along splendidly though it seems a little slow
to her.

I am very much interested in your continu-
ing contact with these men who worked with Reed on the
yellow fever. I hope you will continue this and if we
ever put across the program of which we have been
talking we will make that the major feature of it. We
have again extended the invitation to Lord Dawson for
Commencement and are awaiting his reply. I will let you
know the minute I hear something.

I would like to hear Kissinger over the
radio but you will not have time now to find out and
I will probably be on the road. Let that pass.

If you work out the stories of these men
I think your name should be honored as well as theirs.
I will be deeply interested in what you work out and
it will be a great thing if we can build this Commence-
ment program up around this story.

Give our love to Mary and the family.
We are going along in good shape now and will be eager
to see you when you come this way again. I may slip
in a trip up there for a checkup examination some time
this winter.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Hutch Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
RCH/M
P.S. Thank you for the clinic! That
means a great deal to me and your saying it
means more.
R.C.H.
